content.intro:
At the heart of majestic Scandinavia, discover Oslo, the multifaceted city of soft lights.

Oslo, formerly Kristiania, has shone upon the countries of the Far North since its foundation in the 11th century. Partly destroyed by fire in 1624, the city was rebuilt, adorning itself from the beginning of the 17th century in the most beautiful colours. Located at the entrance of a large fjord, Oslo remains primarily a city turned towards the sea. Surrounded by green hills and dense forests, the capital of Norway is surrounded by numerous easily accessible islands. Far from the stereotypes and constantly moving forward, Oslo amazes with the creativity and cheerfulness of its inhabitants. Though the climate imposes its laws, the fact remains that the daily life of the Osloites charms with its gentleness and liveliness.

Between Scandinavian design and wilderness excursions, a trip to Oslo will satisfy the desires of everyone. The history of the city may be read in the coloured facades of the district located around the popular Karl Johans Gate. The heart of the city beats here, and over the past several years, numerous museums and galleries have opened their doors.

Oslo can be visited at any time of year, as its many facets offer a diversity of attractions. It is at once urban, rural, and maritime, donning the white lights of the northern winter to the delight of those looking for the thrill of the great Scandinavian north, while the Norwegians' joie de vivre and the islands of Oslo's Fjords will astound you in summer. You may also explore the Norwegian countryside by taking various trains leaving from Oslo's central station. It is a great getaway for experiencing a uniquely relaxing or highly active and original moment.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Oslo

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Oslo  - Plan your trip to Oslo with Air France Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Oslo: what to visit to Oslo, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Oslo with Air France.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Oslo

content.title: Ramme: Munch's old house, between art and educational farm

introduction.small: About 40 km south of the Norwegian capital, walk in the footsteps of Expressionist painter Edvard Munch in Ramme. A cultural centre and organic farm for the whole family.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ramme: Munch's old house, between art and educational farm

paragraphs.text:
Nature and culture sometimes come in pair. Right outside Oslo, experience both in Ramme, where every generation will find something of interest. An organic farm reveals its eco-friendly methods, as well as traditional livestock and cattle farming. All around, a huge park of baroque style includes fountains, flower beds and rose gardens. However, art remains at the core, benefitting from the location of the cultural centre, situated on the former estate of Expressionist painter Edvard Munch (whose old house can be visited), and from the programming of various events. The gallery offers both permanent and temporary exhibitions, mainly concentrating on Scandinavian painters like Frits Thaulow, Theodor Kittelsen and, of course, Edvard Munch himself, who created some of his most wondrous works in Ramme. The selection of his works will put you in the artist's shoes to discover the landscapes that fuelled his imagination until the end of his life.

Theatre plays and concerts complete the cultural centre's abundant offer. Sometimes, the surrounding park is used to stage Shakespeare classics. One must admit that, between the forest and the sea, Ramme dons heavenly clothes. In the words of Edvard Munch, “this place is assuredly the most beautiful on the entire coast”.

Ramme
Rammeveien 90
1545 Hvitsten

+47 649 83 200

https://www.ramme.no/no/

content.title: Grünerløkka and Grønland: explore Oslo's alternative neighbourhoods

introduction.small: Far from the peaceful and classic Oslo you may know, explore the city's underground, between Brooklyn-like Grünerløkka and multicultural Grønland.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grünerløkka and Grønland: explore Oslo's alternative neighbourhoods

paragraphs.text:
Characterised by the flow of the Akerselva river, Grünerløkka takes visitors thousands of miles from Oslo with its typical Brooklyn atmosphere. Very much like the New York borough, it has been an attractive location for all vintage lovers, who walk up and down Markveien street and visit its retro thrift shops. Have a coffee on Olaf Ryes square and get a whiff of the neighbourhood's lingering spirit, across from the Parkteatret, Norway's very first movie theatre opened in 1907. Take a trip to one of the several nearby parks crossed by the river which forms waterfalls at certain points. Follow it downstream until you can smell the aroma of various spices. Then you will know you have arrived in Grønland, Oslo's multicultural district, where exotic and traditional restaurants coexist. This is where the foundations of the capital were built, around year 1000. Some ruins can still be seen near the Saint Olav monastery (13th century). A thousand years later, it has become a trendy spot, conceived around Oslo Mekaniske Verksted as a focal point. This former mechanical equipment factory has been converted into a lively hub that welcomes a theatre and a bohemian-looking bar, where the local and trendy youth likes to gather. A true must to get a real feel of the city!

Grünerløkka
0552 Oslo
https://www.visitoslo.com/fr/activites-et-sites/quartiers/grunerlokka/

Parkteatret
Olaf Ryes plass 11
0552 Oslo
Tel : +47 223 56 300
https://parkteatret.no/englsih-info/

Olso Mekaniske Verksted
Tøyenbekken 34
0188 Oslo
Tel : +47 452 37 534
https://www.oslomekaniskeverksted.no

Monastère Saint-Olav (St. Olav Katolske Domkirkemenighet)
Akersveien 1
0192 Oslo
https://www.visitoslo.com/fr/produit/?tlp=2987033&name=St-Olav-s-Catholic-Church

content.title: Amerikalinjen, tribute to Norwegian emigrants

introduction.small: Close to the Oslo opera house, Kvadraturen (fashionistas' favourite street) and Youngstorget, a district popular with night owls, the Amerikalinjen hotel is a witness to Norway's migratory past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Amerikalinjen, tribute to Norwegian emigrants

paragraphs.text:
A testimony to Norway's past, the former headquarters of the Norwegian America Line shipping company, built in 1919, have seen thousands of people set foot in, all looking ahead to crossing the Atlantic for a better life in the United States. Before Norway became one of the biggest oil exporters, its economy was essentially based on cod fishing and livestock farming.

Inside what used to be the company's Neobaroque building, a hotel has since then opened, while keeping its Norwegian name, Amerikalinjen. Far from a vindication of the American way of life, the establishment is a tribute to local savoir-faire: from staff uniforms to room furniture and bathroom amenities, everything is made in Norway. Moreover, the hotel's contemporary design does not capitalize on nostalgia for a bygone era. There are no seaman pea-jackets, no 20th-century luggage to be found in the rooms, merely a few pictures along with the hotel's New York-inspired jazz club, Gustav, that do witness to the origins of Amerikalinjen. Attention has been paid on craftsmanship and current Norwegian design instead. They will give a perfect overview of what 21st-century Oslo life is all about.

Amerikalinjen
Jernbanetorget 2
0154 Oslo

+47 214 05 900

https://amerikalinjen.com

Rooms: from 2,036 NOK

content.title: FYR, bistronomy, the Nordic way

introduction.small: Sheltered from view in the basement of a lovely villa in Oslo, FYR unveils intimate atmosphere and refined cuisine inspired from Norwegian local recipes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: FYR, bistronomy, the Nordic way

paragraphs.text:
The large Norwegian villa with exposed stone walls hides FYR in its midst. A restaurant set… in a cellar! Under the brick arches, wooden tables, modern chairs and mouse grey beach seats are lining up in a pared-down and relaxing atmosphere. Behind the counter, you can observe frenzied activity in the kitchen, orchestrated by chef Sebastian Myrhe. Within the bistronomy trend, he devised a menu inspired by Nordic fine dining that however remains accessible by also drawing inspiration from bistro classics. The dishes lack no refinement, see for yourself: grilled lamb, chorizo, kale and fermented garlic, or grilled wagyu bacon with celeriac, quince and cream, as well as grilled rib steak with beetroot, gnocchi and chestnuts… Food lovers may be tempted by one of the two chef's tasting menus, showcasing the full range of Sebastian Myrhe's talent. Also a wine bar, FYR can offer dinner and wine pairing upon request, which is the best option to sublimate this Nordic gustatory experience.

FYR Bistronomi & Bar
Underhaugsveien 28
0354 Oslo

+47 459 16 392

https://www.fyrbistronomi.no

Menu: around 400 NOK

content.title: Vigeland, the largest sculpture park in the world by one artist

introduction.small: More than 200 sculptures are in the permanent exhibition of Vigeland Park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vigeland, the largest sculpture park in the world by one artist

paragraphs.text:
Within the Frognerparken, the largest public park in Oslo, you will actually find the Vigeland Park, conceived by Norwegian sculptor Gustav Vigeland. Visited every year by more than a million people, this open-sky museum is on the list of the most popular attractions in Norway. The park lets you stroll through its paths while admiring 200 of Vigeland's creations from the first half of the 20th century, the accomplishment of decades of work.

In bronze, granite or iron, the statues represent the cycle of human life, from birth until death, and show women and men exhibiting their feelings of happiness, pain, hope and yearning for freedom. Among the most famous sculptures, do not miss out on a 17-metre high monolith made up of a hundred interlaced characters, or that of an angry child, that has become one of the symbols of Oslo and that you will see on many postcards.

Vigeland Sculpture Park (Vigelandsparken)
Frognerparken
Nobels gate 32
0268 Oslo

+47 234 93 700

https://vigeland.museum.no/en/vigelandpark

content.title: F5 Concept Store, the best of Norwegian fashion

introduction.small: With its 100% Norwegian selection, this concept store dedicated to men's and women's clothing, was designed for fashion lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: F5 Concept Store, the best of Norwegian fashion

paragraphs.text:
Oslo stands out for its global open-mindedness by anticipating the next new thing. Influenced by a bohemian touch, the city is nestled with original shops up to date with the latest trends. The F5 Concept Store perfectly illustrates the Norwegians' appetite for design from every angle, especially fashion.

Founded by brothers Emil and Benjamin Marthinsen, themselves designers, F5 sees itself as a showcase of the cutting-edge creativity of the Norwegian connection. From simple cuts in beautiful materials, style and functionality are the hallmarks of its pursuit of excellence. Moiré, F5, Catherine Hammel, SOSTER STUDIO; the constantly renewed selection will not fail to surprise you! The myriad of designers displayed there are exclusively from the finest of Norwegian fashion.

Give into your shopping desires in their beautiful, refined space, which can be visited like a contemporary art gallery.

F5 Concept Store
Prinsens gate 6
0152 Oslo

+47 941 19 317

https://f5conceptstore.com

content.title: Elias mat & sånt, Scandinavia on a plate!

introduction.small: Bright and refined, this small restaurant invites you to discover delicious and healthy dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Elias mat & sånt, Scandinavia on a plate!

paragraphs.text:
Near the National Gallery in the Tullinløkka district, Elias mat & sånt is a perfect stop for those who wish to try a gourmet meal while taking care of their health. While in Norway "cuisine" almost rhymes with healthy, Elias mat & sånt has made it its trademark. Focusing on organic ingredients, the menu puts the spotlight on healthy regional products. Salmon, dried fish, vegan steak, vegetable and fruit salads and mushroom soup, the dishes are all homemade and give you a feel of the country.

Try the braised ham hock served with potato mash, vegetables and a game and cranberry sauce, or indulge in oven-baked goat cheese with honey-roasted beetroot and candied nuts. To accompany these dishes, choose from among freshly squeezed fruit juices, a glass of organic milk or even non-alcoholic beer.

Light wood furniture, dim lighting, book-lined shelves… the place exudes the good life. Do not hesitate, rush for it!

Elias mat & sånt
Kristian Augusts gate 14
0164 Oslo

+47 222 02 221

https://www.cafeelias.no/en/

Menu: around 250 NOK

content.title: Peloton, a sporty kind of café

introduction.small: This trendy cafe in the Norwegian capital will delight all cycling enthusiasts… as well as others!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peloton, a sporty kind of café

paragraphs.text:
At Peloton, we love cycling and we don't hide it. Located on Torggata, one of Oslo's largest cycling arteries, the establishment is among one of the many “cycling cafes” that have flourished in recent years in a country known for its daily use of two wheels.

Its added value? Excellent coffee, beer, succulent pizza revisited in a Scandinavian fashion and a very relaxed setting. For instance, try the Salsiccia pizza with spinach, garlic, hot pepper, potatoes, sausage, mozzarella, rosemary and fennel seeds… A pure delight! Like a tribute to cycling competitions, its ceiling is adorned with a multitude of multi-coloured pennants, racing bikes and runners' caps. Large tables invite sharing; it is not uncommon for regulars to rush to watch sports broadcasts together, on the big screen, such as the Tour de France, the Giro (Tour of Italy) and the Vuelta (Tour of Spain)… especially since this cycling lovers meeting spot is open until 3:00 in the morning!

Peloton
Torggata 35
0183 Oslo

+47 921 56 181

https://pelotonbar.squarespace.com/english-menu

Menu: around 200 NOK

content.title: Vippa, with the fjord for decor

introduction.small: Looking for an alternative trendy bar? Vippa will make all of your wishes come true!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vippa, with the fjord for decor

paragraphs.text:
A perfect account of the Scandinavian spirit, Vippa wins all the votes. Established on the docks of Oslo in April 2017, at the end of the pier, it offers after work get-togethers, concerts and lectures, among many other events. A former hangar, this immense space with graffiti-covered walls now houses various stalls with fish-based snacks, one more delicious than the next. At any time of the day you can also taste a fish & chips, facing the fjord.

The place upholds a simple objective: to bring together Oslovians and tourists around the cuisine and culture. While eating remains a social bond, it also includes partying. Thus, during crab season in October, Vippa celebrates shellfish. On the menu, fresh crab and ille brød (black bread), mayonnaise, aioli, lemon and dill. Everything is a treat, with CrabDJ in the background, of course!

Vippa
Akershusstranda 25
0150 Oslo

+47 917 28 043

https://www.vippa.no/

Menu: around 150 NOK

content.title: Engebret Café, local institution

introduction.small: In a quaint atmosphere, an ideal restaurant to try out local gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Engebret Café, local institution

paragraphs.text:
The Engebret has no equivalent for those looking to try good Scandinavian food. It is an elegant restaurant, set in a house dating from the 17th century. You can taste one of the classics of Nordic gastronomy: reindeer meat, as well as the lutefisk typical dish during holiday periods. A recipe based on marinated and pickled fish, with strong flavours that recall ancient Viking culture. Here, it is served with potatoes, another staple of traditional Norwegian cooking. For starters, try the king crab baked in oven with a lemon cream, or the salmon tartare prepared with egg yolk and horseradish, served on a bed of cress.

In terms of decoration, wood panelling and plush large curtains warm the atmosphere and give the whole a typical Nordic style.

On the walls, there are pictures of the great personalities of the country who have dined in this key location in Oslo. Since you are in the theatre district, celebrate with an improvised cultural and authentic evening, in the image of Oslo itself.

Engebret Café
Bankplassen 1
0151 Oslo

+47 228 22 525

https://www.engebret-cafe.no/english

Menu: around 600 NOK

content.title: Fjord, fresh and seasonal fish in the spotlight

introduction.small: Exquisite Norwegian cuisine in a place loaded with character.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fjord, fresh and seasonal fish in the spotlight

paragraphs.text:
Go through the door of this trendy Oslo restaurant to enjoy delicious fish and other dishes cooked with masterful Norwegian expertise. The plates are beautifully prepared, and ingredients cleverly combined for discovering the flavours of Norwegian cuisine through three to five dish menus, as you wish.

The menus change regularly, according to the seasons and the inspirations of the team. The associations orchestrated by the chef, such as smoked cod, mussels and saffron mayo, smoked haddock with potatoes and red wine sauce, as well as mango Munster cheese profiterole for dessert, all reveal true originality.

The portions are small, but the food is excellent! The walls, illuminated in blue, give the restaurant a surprisingly warm and friendly glow. The wine list offers an excellent selection of European wines, with a showcase of French vineyards. Located a few steps only from the National Museum, this is the ideal spot for organising a cultural afternoon followed by a gourmet evening!

Restaurant Fjord
Kristian Augusts Gate 11
0164 Oslo

+47 229 82 150

https://restaurantfjord.no

Menu: from 445 NOK

content.title: Architecture, music and gastronomy at Oslo's Opera

introduction.small: Enjoy a visit to the opera, built in 2008 directly on the fjord.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Architecture, music and gastronomy at Oslo's Opera

paragraphs.text:
Dressed all in glass, the building astounds by its modernity and beauty. This immense sculpted space symbolises all the attention that Norwegians bring to art and culture. Its large white marble roof makes it possible to walk along the promenade that is, surprisingly, found there, and to enjoy stunning views of Oslo and the Oslo Fjord.

One of the facades is equipped with solar panels that provide the building with a part of the energy it consumes. Lovers of ballet and classical and contemporary music will enjoy the remarkable programme of this cultural institution, which has been a big hit with both the Norwegian and the international public.

Its main auditorium is considered to be one of the most sophisticated in the world. The opera offers exciting, behind-the-scenes tours of the life and functioning of the monument. You can also reserve a table in the delightful Sanguine Brasserie before the show, and so enjoy the view over the fjord. A gala evening you will not forget.

Den Norske Opera & Ballett (Oslo Opera House)
Kirsten Flagstads plass 1
0150 Oslo

+47 214 22 121

https://operaen.no/en

content.title: The Akershus Fortress, Oslo's emblematic monument

introduction.small: The imprint of time and the medieval origins of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Akershus Fortress, Oslo's emblematic monument

paragraphs.text:
Built in the 13th century under Håkon V, the Akershus Fortress (“Akershus festning” in Norwegian) was for a long time the residence of the kings of Norway, and remains today one of the emblems of power. Its strategic location at the seaside makes it an accessible and enjoyable promenade.

The exterior of the fortress recalls its military role in protecting the city, without any doubt, but its interiors were redesigned during the Renaissance into a more comfortable place. History buffs and those who enjoy discoveries from other eras will be delighted by the visit.

Several guided tours are available, one around the history of the fortress on its 700 years of existence, the other centred on the use of it as a prison, which is a guaranteed thrill. Do not miss the crypt in the citadel church, where you will find the royal necropolis containing the tombs of the last kings of Norway. On a friendlier note, during warm weather, picnicking is allowed in the beautiful gardens.

Akershus Fortress (Akershus festning)
0150 Oslo

+47 230 93 917

https://www.visitoslo.com/en/product/?tlp=2978773&name=Akershus-Fortress

content.title: The Thief, between design, comfort and culture

introduction.small: A trendy and surprising address, perfectly situated to discover the city on foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Thief, between design, comfort and culture

paragraphs.text:
Facing the Astrup Fearnley Museum of Modern Art on the Tjuvholmen island, The Thief combines everything you can expect from a designer hotel: premium comfort, hip decor, attentive service and, above all, an excellent opportunity to walk around town.

The building was conceived by the famous Norwegian architecture agency Mellbye with luxurious and refined fabrics in mind, as well as warm and modern colours that give the rooms an elegantly cosy atmosphere. Within its walls, the hotel shelters the Thief Foodbar, a restaurant popular for its weekend brunch, that also serves dishes inspired by Norwegian gastronomy with a touch of international influences.

Finally, the spa invites you to let go in a dark stone atmosphere, bathed in the most successful "fjord" lighting. Note that this unusual hotel offers free entry to the Museum of Modern Art located opposite, and that it regularly holds concerts and exhibitions.

The Thief
Landgangen 1
0252 Oslo

+47 240 04 000

https://thethief.com/en/

Rooms: from 3,631 NOK

content.title: The Nobel Peace Centre, a historical journey

introduction.small: The history of the 20th century is felt as soon as you pass through the door of this legendary place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Nobel Peace Centre, a historical journey

paragraphs.text:
Here is a unique opportunity for you to learn more about this award and its creator. Alfred Nobel, a prestigious Swedish chemist, invented dynamite in the late 19th century and made a fortune through this discovery. During his extensive research, he detonated several explosions, one of which was particularly serious and killed his brother in 1864.

At his death in 1896, he bequeathed his vast fortune to the creation of the various Nobel awards, including the Nobel Peace Prize, which was to reward those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction of standing armies, and for the holding and promotion of peace congresses". According to his will, this prize has been awarded in Oslo on a yearly basis since 1901, while other prizes (for physics, chemistry, literature and so on) are awarded in Stockholm. You can discover the portraits of the winners during your visit.

Martin Luther King, Mother Teresa, and Barack Obama are part of this wall of glory and peace. Guided tours and lectures, as well as activities for children, ensure some family time of historical and cultural value.

Nobel Peace Centre (Nobels Fredssenter)
Brynjulf Bulls plass 1
0250 Oslo

+47 483 01 000

https://www.nobelpeacecenter.org/en

content.title: Oslo designer addresses, a dream for lovers of Scandinavian design

introduction.small: Famous for its trendy design, the Norwegian capital is filled with beautiful shops where to find furniture, lights and decorative items.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oslo designer addresses, a dream for lovers of Scandinavian design

paragraphs.text:
Scandinavian design has never ceased building a fan base and, today, all decoration brands and shops assert their lineage to that inimitable style. If you like natural materials, neutral colours, luminous atmospheres, and simple lines, you will be charmed by the shops in Oslo's city centre.

At Pure Norsk, you can discover more than 50 Norwegian designers gathered together in a huge and warm store. Light wood furniture, sleek and modern design, and warm colours to cheer the whole you will not leave this place empty-handed!

At Eske Interiør & Design, discover another selection of decorative objects and lighting, carefully chosen among the greatest designers of the country.

After those visits to the major hotspots of local decoration, do not miss another emblematic site: the Mortensrud Church, built in 2002, which is an amazing example of Norwegian style. Dressed entirely in slate, its lines will surprise you, as well as the way it melts into the surrounding green-space.

Pure Norsk
Industrigata 36
0357 Oslo
+47 224 64 045
https://purnorsk.no

Eske Interiør & Design
Sofies Gate 16
0170 Oslo
+47 400 05 253
https://www.eskeinterior.no

Mortensrud Church (Mortensrud kirke)
Helga Vaneks vei 15
1281 Oslo
+47 236 29 980
https://www.visitoslo.com/en/product/?tlp=2980053&name=Eglise-de-Mortensrud

content.title: Enjoy the many opportunities Oslo offers to go family skiing.

introduction.small: Enjoy the many opportunities Oslo offers to go family skiing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the many opportunities Oslo offers to go family skiing.

paragraphs.text:
One of the advantages of visiting a capital so close to the Arctic Circle lies in the many ski slopes, natural and artificial, that are accessible from Oslo. The largest resort around Oslo is Vinterpark, located 30 minutes from the city centre in Tryvann, where the World Snowboard Championships were held in 2012. It is easily accessible on foot or by bus when exiting at the Voksenkollen metro station. The Oslo Vinterpark is one of the most popular ski resorts of all Norway, thanks to its famous Tryvannskleiva slope, built in the 1930s.

There, authenticity and modernity coexist, and you can come with your family to enjoy the 18 slopes and 11 lifts. Everything is done to make your life easier, so equipment rental on site is of course available.

For thrill seekers, 20 minutes away from the city centre is the mecca of Nordic skiing, Holmenkollen. It houses the oldest ski museum in the world, where you will learn about the sport's 4,000 years of history. Most importantly, it is known for its ski jumping hill. The Kollensvevet zipline takes you up and down the slope to experience jumping and flying through the air like a true champion while keeping perfectly safe. 361 metres of pure adrenalin rush!

Oslo Vinterpark Tryvann
Tryvannsveien 64
0791 Oslo
+47 221 43 610
https://skimore.no/oslo/en/

Kollensvevet Zipline
Kongeveien 5
0787 Oslo
+47 220 83 000
https://www.kollensvevet.no

content.title: The Norwegian Royal Palace, a must

introduction.small: Open the doors of this splendid powder pink floored palace and live a fairy tale.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Norwegian Royal Palace, a must

paragraphs.text:
Built for the King of Sweden, Karl XIV Johan, between 1824 and 1849, this palace symbolises the union between Sweden and Norway, dating from 1814. Between 1814 and 1905, the two countries formed the United Kingdoms of Sweden and Norway following various alliances formed during the Napoleonic wars.

The union did not last long, but gave birth to this illustrious palace, which remains today the official residence of King Harald V and Queen Sonja, whose private apartments are on the second floor.

Visit the Palace in summer to discover the Great Hall, which runs on two levels. In 2001, it welcomed the wedding ball of Crown Prince Haakon and Princess Mette-Marit. The Bird Room is another wonder in pure Scandinavian neoclassical style: there is little doubt that the painted frescoes representing Norwegian nature and landscapes emblematic of the country will dazzle you.

Norwegian Royal Palace (Det kongelige slott)
Slottspalssen 1
0010 Oslo

+44 220 48 700

https://www.royalcourt.no/seksjon.html?tid=28697&sek=27322

content.title: Maaemo: modernity at the source

introduction.small: At Maaemo, celebrity chef Esben Holmboe Bang perfectly sublimates products used in Norwegian cuisine, and provides unique gustatory experiences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maaemo: modernity at the source

paragraphs.text:
The place surprises from the outset: a space of glass and light, facing the sea with its beautiful bay windows several metres high. The view of Oslo is spectacular, especially at night. The cuisine of Maaemo is a return to basics. There is no artifice here; the whole of Norway comes in dishes prepared with great care by the head of this Michelin-starred restaurant.

Organic fish and berries from the Scandinavian forests, seaweed butter of the North Sea, the ingredients will give you a glimpse of what is done best in the country. Nothing is left to chance in this three-star Michelin restaurant and the dishes, carefully conceived by the team, are almost cooked before your eyes.

Due to the short warm season in Norway, throughout the winter the restaurant's chefs offer infusion cuisine to preserve all the flavours and nutritional benefits. A true gustatory experience, only for dinner as Maaemo is closed for lunch. A piece of advice? Book now!

Maaemo
Dronning Eufemias gate 23
0194 Oslo

+47 221 79 969

https://maaemo.no/

Menu: around 3,000 NOK

content.title: Nordmarka Forest, Oslo's green lung

introduction.small: Total immersion in nature, only 20 minutes from the city centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nordmarka Forest, Oslo's green lung

paragraphs.text:
Very easily accessible by public transport, this extended forest area will enchant you with its unspoilt landscapes and the many activities that are available. It is a magical place, where the Norwegian force of nature in its entirety is expressed, just minutes from the capital.

Nordmarka, literally the "forest of the north", the vast expanse of ancient trees abounds with streams and lakes in which you can enjoy kayaking. Each season brings its charm, and you will be welcome whatever time of year you plan your trip.

Several shelters are accessible to hikers in summer and skiers in winter. You can enjoy full board in some of them. For fishing aficionados, know that the lakes are full of fish and it is very easy to buy a license allowing you to fish there - in the respect of quotas and eco-diversity. It is a wonderful getaway, not to be missed!

Nordmarka
0184 Oslo
https://www.visitoslo.com/en/articles/nordmarka-forest/

Oslomarkas Fiskeadministrasjon
Sørkedalsveien 617
0758 Oslo
+47 400 06 768
https://www.ofa.no/fishing-rules/

Den Norske Turistforening
Youngstorget 1
0181 Oslo
+47 400 01 868
https://english.dnt.no/

Skiforeningen
Kongeveien 5
0787 Oslo
+47 229 23 200
https://www.skiforeningen.no

content.title: Lysebu, a romantic getaway a few kilometres from Oslo

introduction.small: A soothing and typically Norwegian place, perfect to reconnect with nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lysebu, a romantic getaway a few kilometres from Oslo

paragraphs.text:
On the Tryvannshøyden hill overlooking Oslo, and only 750 metres from the Voksenkollen metro station, nature lovers and those who hesitate between city and countryside have found the perfect place there. The forest is everywhere. Oaks and century-old larch trees adorn the breathtaking views available from the hotel's rooms.

In the style of a beautiful house in traditional wood, you will find Lysebu foremost a soft and warm refuge: cosy in winter, when snow forms a cocoon around the hotel, and a bright atmosphere in summer, when the sun radiates outside.

The rooms combine comfort and harmony, while the spa allows you to enjoy a moment of Norwegian wellness. Expertly run by chef Andreas Andersson, the restaurant offers refined local cuisine that is decidedly fresh. Try the smoked halibut with mussels, fennel, avocado cream and buckwheat crumble, or the preserved chicken leg in celeriac, apple and cress. The surrounding views of nature bring a little extra something that will make your dinner a unique experience.

Lysebu
Lysebuveien 12
0790 Oslo

+47 215 11 000

www.lysebu.no/en

Rooms: from 1,895 NOK

content.title: Oslo's Fjord Islands, a wonder of the great north

introduction.small: Take a ferry to discover these idyllic islands for an unforgettable journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oslo's Fjord Islands, a wonder of the great north

paragraphs.text:
The 40 islands off Oslo constitute a magnificent natural archipelago, and each of them is a reserve for Norwegian fauna and flora. From the lively Aker Brygge wharf district, guests can board a ferry that takes you to one of the islands, when the season permits.

The most popular is Lindøya, located 20 minutes away from Oslo. The small and coloured wooden houses, hidden swimming areas and natural reserves all create a calm and serene environment. From the Bygdøy Peninsula, you can admire the summer residence of the kings of Norway.

Just in front of Oslo, Hovedøya Island is the ideal place to enjoy the beach in summer. Contrary to popular belief, the Gulf Stream ensures a milder climate in Oslo than its latitude suggests, and fjord water can reach 16°C in August! Finally, if you want to visit them all, the Oslo Grand Tour offers the opportunity of combining a visit to Oslo and its islands, in seven hours, on a beautiful boat.

Norway Yacht Charter
Rådhusbrygge 3
0116 Oslo

+47 233 56 890

https://www.visitoslo.com/en/product/?tlp=2981103&name=D-ile-en-ile-dans-le-fjord-d-Oslo

content.title: Grand Hotel Oslo, the tradition of elegance

introduction.small: A key address in Oslo to walk in the footsteps of the most famous Nobel laureates.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Hotel Oslo, the tradition of elegance

paragraphs.text:
Located on the famous Karl Johans gate, one of the most famous streets of the capital, the Grand Hotel Oslo has no equivalent in the city in terms of reputation. You will fall immediately in love with this place, which perfectly blends tradition, authenticity and design, welcoming you to that most emblematic part of the Norwegian spirit: the perfect blend of past and present.

The rooms, all spacious and nicely furnished, offer simplicity and comfort in a very neat atmosphere. One night in the Nobel Suite accompanies every prestigious award, and so many Nobel laureates have stayed at this historic hotel.

Slightly Baroque, the restaurant decoration of the Palmen, as well as the excellent cuisine that is served there, attracts a very chic and cosmopolitan clientele. To complete a stay that is already rich in sensations, enjoy a retreat in the hotel's spa, which features an indoor pool. The ideal stopover during your winter stay.

Grand Hotel Oslo
Karl Johans gate 31
0159 Oslo

+47 232 12 000

https://www.grand.no/en/home.html

Rooms: from 2,290 NOK

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Oslo
content.introduction: Oslo has a humid continental climate, moderated by the proximity of the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream. Winters are dry and cold, with temperatures staying below freezing from November to March. Significant snowfall is common in the city throughout the winter. Summers are relatively warm and sunny.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Norway is the Norwegian Krone (NOK).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Oslo Gardermoen International Airport
airports.description:
The Oslo Gardermoen International Airport is located about 35 kilometres (22 miles) north-east of the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Oslo and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the E18. It takes about 40 minutes to reach the city centre.
    • The airport offers a total of nearly 19,000 parking spaces, distributed across six parking facilities: drop-off area (first seven minutes are free, then NOK 70 per extra 20 minutes), short-term (NOK 90 per hour) and long-term (NOK 55 per hour).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall on the west side near the railway station.
  • By rail
    • Flytoget (https://flytoget.no/en/), the express rail connection between the airport and Oslo S (the main train station), runs every 10 minutes. The trip takes about 20 minutes and a single ticket costs NOK 199.
  • By bus
    • Ruter-buses (https://ruter.no/en/) connect the airport to the city centre in about 50 minutes. A single ticket costs NOK 133.
  • By shuttle bus
    • Flybussen (https://www.flybussen.no) runs a daily shuttle bus service connecting the airport with the main bus station in the city centre every 20 minutes. The travel time is about 45 minutes and the fare is NOK 185 each way.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the arrivals hall. Fares between the airport and central Oslo range from NOK 600 to NOK 800.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +47 648 10 000
  • Website: https://avinor.no/en/airport/oslo-airport/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Oslo
transportation.description: Oslo is a very easy city to get around. The Norwegian capital's public transport system is one of the most efficient in the world. Furthermore, as many of the sights in Oslo are not that far apart, it is entirely conceivable to explore the city uniquely on foot or by bicycle.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Oslo, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Oslo Visitor Centre
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Jernbanetorget 1 (in Østbanehallen next to Oslo Central Station)
  • Telephone: +47 23 10 62 00
  • Opening hours: 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday to Saturday and 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday (holiday season)
  • Website: https://www.visitoslo.com/en/

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Oslo counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Norway. For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no food safety risks in Oslo.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Oslo.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Norwegian phrases that will make your stay in Oslo a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: God dag
What time is it?: Hvor mye er klokken?
Where can I find (…)?: Hvor kan jeg finne (…)?
Where can I buy (…)?: Hvor kan jeg kjøpe (…)?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Oslo
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Oslo each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On that day, Oslovians gather in various parks for picnic parties organised by labour unions. It is an opportunity for workers to meet other colleagues in a festive atmosphere

events.title: May 15: Saint Hallvard's Day (local event)
events.description: This traditional festival celebrates Oslo's patron saint. Festivities give way to a ceremony, with speeches by the mayor, as well as various cultural events (conferences, guided tours of the historic centre), to introduce visitors to the Norwegian capital's unusual tourist sites.

events.title: May 17: Constitution Day (national event)
events.description: Commemorates the adoption of Norway's constitution on this day in 1814, granting the country more independence from Denmark. Highlights include costume and children's parades, traditional family feasts and official ceremonies.

events.title: First Saturday in June: Musikkfest festival (local event)
events.description: The Musikkfest free music festival is Oslo's first major event of the summer, featuring performances of all styles of music by both Norwegian and international artists at nearly 30 outdoor venues throughout the city.

events.title: Fourth week in July: Norway Cup (local event)
events.description: Established in 1972, this international football tournament for children and youths aged 10–19 is one of the largest events of its kind anywhere in the world, drawing some 30,000 participants from many countries every year.

events.title: Second week in August: Mela Festival (local event)
events.description: This major festival held on the Rådhusplassen (City Hall Square) offers free admission to its entire programme of events, featuring artistic and cultural expressions from all over the world: music, arts and crafts, film, theatre and dance. In addition, the colours and scents of world cuisines are celebrated by the range of delectable delights sold at the food stalls.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Norway
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Norway for less than three months. However, your national identity card or passport must be valid for the duration of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Oslo and Norway, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Norway page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs travel Website:

view information for travellers to Norway

banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March

End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Oslo as in the rest of Norway, a service charge is usually already included in restaurant bills and taxi fares, but you can certainly reward good service with a 10% tip.
